Inorganic Materials and Catalysis Division CSIR-Central Salt and Marine Chemicals Research Institute Council of Scientific and Industrial Research (CSIR) Bhavnagar 364 002 India Graphical abstract A novel material, hydrous ruthenium oxide (HRO) as potential catalyst precursor, is reported for the selective hydrogenation of levulinic acid (LA) to γ-valerolactone (γ-VL) in high yields under the mildest conditions in an aqueous medium. Various characterization studies such as PXRD, FT-IR, TGA, SEM, TEM and XPS show that the active catalyst, referred here as Ru-HRO is generated in situ from HRO during the reaction. Such in situ generation of the active catalyst thus avoided prior reduction or pre-treatment which is often reported for Ru-based catalysts for this reaction. It is pertinent to mention that the activity of the in situ generated catalyst is higher than the ex situ reduced catalyst. The effect of H-β as support for HRO showed a pronounced influence on the active catalyst (Ru-HRO@H-β) by decreasing the Ru loading required (compared to ‘as such’ HRO) and rendered easier separation after the reaction. Interestingly, the HRO-derived catalyst works only under aqueous medium unlike in many organic solvents reported elsewhere. A reaction mechanism is proposed by using several controlled experiments which reveal hydrogenation of LA to γ-hydroxypentanoic acid (γ-HP) and followed by cyclisation (intramolecular esterification) to γ-VL with the removal of H2O. The catalyst showed similar activity upon recycling for up to five cycles and for the reaction scale (of LA) from 1 g to 200 g. Further, liquid phase continuous hydrogenation of LA to γ-VL is successfully demonstrated using in situ generated Ru-HRO@H-β (dual bed) in aqueous medium under optimized reaction condition (1.5 ml/min of aqueous LA feed flow (5 wt%), 100 °C, 10 bar H2 and 2 ml/min flow of H2 feed), that showed complete conversion of LA with 98–100% yield of γ-VL for 40 h time-on-stream. Simple preparation method, milder reaction conditions, high activity, recyclability, and ability to deploy under continuous conditions makes this catalytic process attractive for industrial production of γ-VL. The use of bio-based feedstock limits the greenhouse house gas (GHG) emissions and enhances the rural development when compared with fossil feedstock [1–4]. Several research groups worldwide are involved in the production of varieties of chemical building blocks from biomass for societal needs such as biodiesel, furans, carboxylic acids, polyols, aromatics and other organic components by thermochemical and bio/chemo-catalytic transformations [5–11]. Levulinic acid (LA), a keto carboxylic acid that can easily be obtained through acid hydrolysis of lignocellulosic biomass, is of utmost industrial importance owing to the facile transformation of its functional groups resulting in a gamut of value added products [12–21]. γ-valerolactone (γ-VL), an attractive platform chemical obtained by selective hydrogenation of LA, is used in the preparation of a variety of fuels, polymers and chemical intermediates and acts itself as a greener alternative solvent for various chemical transformations and is also reported as a good medium for the conversion of lignocellulose components (Figs. S1–S3 in the ESI) [22,23]. The research groups of Regina Palkovits, Pierluigi Barbaro, Shijie Liu, and Karen Wilson and others have contributed extensive reviews on heterogeneous as well as homogeneous catalytic processes for the conversion of LA to γ-VL using different hydrogenation sources such as molecular hydrogen, formic acid, alcohols etc. [24–27]. Molecular hydrogen is the most common and industrially suitable hydrogenating agent to convert LA to γ-VL. Complexes of Ru/Ir/Pd etc. are quite active for the mentioned conversion [28–32]; however, homogeneous catalytic systems suffer from an inherent problem of separation and disposal of the spent catalyst. Often the synthesis of such complexes requires expensive chemicals and multistep reaction protocols thus decreasing their suitability for industrial processes. A number of heterogeneous catalytic systems have been reported based on supported noble (Ru, Pd, Pt, Au) and non-noble (Ni, Cu, Co, Mo etc) metal based catalysts, each showing considerable activity towards LA to γ-VL conversion. Among them, Ru catalysts are widely reported showing better activity under comparatively milder reaction conditions. The prior art of this conversion using Ru-based catalysts are presented in Table S1A–C in the ESI. Considering Ru-based catalysts, the hydrogenation of LA to γ-VL was initially studied with 5% Ru/C and reported a maximum conversion of LA and yield of γ-VL in different solvent medium. To increase the stability of the catalyst in acidic medium (used in the production of levulinic acid from cellulose), bimetallic catalytic system was introduced by doping Ru/C with Sn and Re [33,34] These catalysts (RuSn/C and RuRe/C) showed good stability compared to conventional Ru/C. Furthermore, to improve the stability of Ru catalyst, ZrO2 as support in acidic dioxane medium was studied which avoided the deactivation/leaching issues when compared with carbon supported Ru catalyst [35]. Enhancement in the rate of reaction was observed while using Amberlyst-70 as a co-catalyst to Ru/C. Using this bi-catalytic system in aqueous medium, γ-VL was obtained in 99% yield at 70 °C, 5 bar H2 in 3 h. The authors concluded that presence of acid co-catalyst facilitates reaction via two mechanistic pathways, and thus enabling under milder reaction conditions [36]. In an endeavour to develop an efficient process for this conversion, various research groups have reported Ru catalysts on different kinds of supports including acidic, basic as well as neutral supports (e.g., carbon, Al2O3, SiO2, ZrO2@C, TiO2, hydroxyapatite, polyethersulfone, H-β, Dowex resin, TiSi2O6 and Mg-LaO) in literature [37–48]. The Ru nanoparticles derived from [Ru3(CO)12] showed 100% yield of γ-VL from LA at 130 °C, 5 bar H2 in 12 h in water [49]. Ru nanoparticles supported on ordered mesoporous carbon (OMC) showed superior activity compared to commercial Ru/C under equivalent conditions (150 °C, 45 b H2, 2 h), and the catalyst showed better recyclability and stability [50]. Ni doped Ru (Ru0.9Ni0.1) catalyst on OMC is highly active and stable up to several reaction cycles under same reaction conditions as that of Ru/OMC [51]. Researchers, to improve the catalyst efficiency further, modified the OMC by using a N-dopant (5% Ru/NOMC) and reported 100% yield of γ-VL at 120 °C, 13 bar H2 in 4 h in methanolic medium [52]. However, the reported catalytic systems for LA to γ-VL conversion have several drawbacks including high energy requirements for the preparation of catalyst (TableS1A–C in the ESI) which at many times higher than that required for the reaction, harsh reaction conditions (high temperature and H2 pressure), use of environmentally polluting organic solvents, increase in cost owing to the use of expensive catalyst precursors involving multistep processes, poor recyclability due to leaching of metal from the catalytic support etc. These drawbacks preclude the effective use of such catalysts for industrial scale synthesis of γ-VL from LA. Considering above drawbacks from literature, this work is aimed to synthesize a Ru-based heterogeneous catalyst, here hydrous ruthenium oxide (HRO), by a simple method that would preclude the use of acidic additives or co-catalyst for the selective hydrogenation of LA to γ-VL under benign reaction conditions in aqueous medium without suffering from the previously mentioned deficiencies. Nearly stoichiometric yield (>99%) was obtained under the mildest reaction conditions (50 °C in 30 min) hitherto not reported. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalysts preparation 2.1.1 Preparation of HRO HRO catalyst was prepared by a simple precipitation method, a solution 0.001 M of RuCl3 was added to appropriate amount of CaCO3 aqueous solution and allowed to stand for 1 h without any stirring and heating. The obtained precipitate was washed with water for several times for removal of chloride ions (confirmed with AgNO3 solution) and dried for 3 h at 100 °C. The prepared material is as assigned the code HRO. 2.1.2 Preparation of HRO-N In a typical synthesis of HRO, 0.001 M RuCl3 solution was adjusted to pH > 13.2 with drop wise addition of 1 M aq. NaOH solution, stirred at room temperature for 24 h and allowed to stand undisturbed for 12 h. The obtained precipitate was washed with water for several times for removal of chloride ions and dried for 3 h at 100 °C. The prepared material is referred to as HRO-N in the following sections. 2.1.3 HRO-S Hydrous ruthenium oxide (HRO-S) was purchased from Sigma Aldrich and used as a standard for comparison purposes with our synthesized catalysts. 2.1.4 Preparation of HRO/H-β HRO supported on H-β zeolite was prepared by simultaneous precipitation of HRO and its impregnation on H-β zeolite. The 0.001 M of RuCl3 solution is mixed with appropriate amount of aqueous CaCO3 solution and desired amount of zeolite, the resulting mixture was stirred up to 12 h at room temperature; the obtained precipitate was washed with water and dried for 3 h at 100 °C. The material is known as HRO/ H-β. Recovered HRO/H-β after catalysis has been referred to as Ru-HRO@H-β. 2.1.5 Preparation of RuO2 RuO2 catalyst was prepared by calcination of HRO at 550 °C for 3 h at 10 °C/min ramp rate. 2.2 Hydrogenation of levulinic acid Levulinic acid (98%), methyl levulinate (≥ 98%), γ-valerolactone (99%), TiO2, Carbon, MgAl-LDH, RuO2.xH2O and RuCl3.xH2O were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich, 5% Ru/Al2O3 was purchased from Johnson Matthey, metal salts and hydrogen (>99.99% purity) were purchased from the local market, India. The zeolite was purchased from Zeochem, Switzerland. The LA hydrogenation experiments were carried out in a Hastelloy Amar high pressure reactor (Mumbai, India). The reactions were repeated in a stainless steel Autoclave Engineering high pressure reactor (USA), 100 ml equipped with an electrically heated jacket and mechanical stirrer. The reactor was loaded with the catalyst and the substrate (LA) dissolved in the solvent, purged with N2 three times before pressurizing with a fixed amount of H2 and the reaction was carried out at desirable temperatures and time duration. After completion of the reaction the reactor was cooled to room temperature and the excess H2 was released. The catalyst was separated by simple centrifugation and used for next cycle without any pre-treatment. The quantitative analysis of product mixture was done by using Shimadzu-UHPLC system equipped with PDI detector using Supelcogel-610H column. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization The synthesised HROs were characterized by various analytical techniques like PXRD, XPS, SEM, TEM, NH3-TPD, TPR, TGA, FT-IR and ICP. PXRD patterns of HROs (HRO: prepared by using CaCO3 as precipitating agent, HRO-N: prepared by using NaOH as precipitating agent and HRO-S (Sigma-Aldrich)) did not show any diffraction peaks and confirms that the material is amorphous in nature Fig. 2 A. The calcined HRO denoted as RuO2 showed intense peaks of 110, 101, 200, 211, 220, 002, 310, 112, 301 and 201 planes corresponding to tetragonal RuO2 (JCPDS card no. 21-1172) Fig. 2A. After impregnation of HRO on Na/H-β zeolite the crystallinity of the parent zeolite remained unchanged Fig. 2B. FT-IR spectra of HROs (Fig. 4) showed a broad band centred at 3440 cm−1 due to OH stretching of strongly bonded water molecules. The absence of such band in the case of RuO2 is due to the lack of water molecules on its surface. In TGA of HRO material (Fig. 5), a sharp weight loss was observed in the temperature range of 260–310 °C attributed to removal of strongly held H2O molecules. On the other hand, RuO2 did not show any weight loss in the entire temperature range studied viz., 50–800 °C, suggesting the absence of H2O molecules. The TPR profile of HRO and RuO2 showed a broad reduction peak in the range of 150–600 °C and 300–800 °C suggests a lesser reduction temperature of HRO than RuO2 (Fig. 6). In NH3-TPD analysis, HRO gave intense desorption peak at 240 °C indicating that the material has high acidity and the temperature window suggests sites with weak to moderate strength (Fig. S4 in the ESI). The TEM images of HRO (Fig. 7A) showed that the particles are highly agglomerated which may due to the interaction of neighbouring Ru particles through oxygen atoms. The agglomeration among particles was also confirmed by SEM (Fig. S5A in the ESI). The TEM images of HRO/H-β zeolite showed that the corresponding particles of HRO are well-dispersed on H-β zeolite support (Fig. 7C). The HRO material was synthesized in several batches to check the consistency of Ru loading wherein the ICP-OES results showed 95–100% efficient reproducibility of the material. The calculated Ru (in wt. %) of HRO loaded on different supports (cellulose, carbon, TiO2, MgAl-LDH and H-β) shows highest loading of 3.2 wt% for H-β against an expected loading of 4 wt%. The textural properties of materials are mentioned in Table 4. The BET surface area of HRO was found to be 85 m2/g and that of H-β support is 500 m2/g. After impreganation of HRO material on H-β (HRO/H-β), a decrease in the surface area was observed to 397 m2/g, probably due to coverage/blockage of pores by HRO partcicles. 3.2 Catalytic activity The catalytic activity of HRO material towards selective hydrogenation of LA to γ-VL was tested in aqueous medium pressurized with 20 bar H2 at 120 °C. The active catalyst generated in situ during the reaction, referred here as Ru-HRO, whose composition would be discussed vide infra, exhibited complete conversion in 1 h. A control experiment without any catalyst did not give any appreciable LA conversion (Table 1 , entries 1 and 2). We strived to achieve a more economical process by altering the material loading, pressure of H2, and the reaction temperature. HRO content varied from 10 mg (0.5 wt% of Ru w.r.t LA) to 2.5 mg (0.125 wt% of Ru w.r.t LA) keeping the reaction temperature and pressure constant. It was observed that 3.5 mg of HRO (0.175 wt% of Ru w.r.t LA) was sufficient for complete conversion of 1 g LA to 0.86 g γ-VL at 120 °C and 20 bar H2 (Table 1, entries 2–5). We decreased the H2 pressure from initial 20 bar to atmospheric pressure, keeping HRO loading fixed at 3.5 mg. It was observed that 5 bar H2 is optimal for selective hydrogenation of LA at 120 °C (Table 1, entries 5–8). Further, reaction was successful even by decreasing the reaction temperature from 120 °C to 50 °C without any compromise in the conversion of LA and selectivity of γ-VL (Table 1, entries 8–10). In addition, it was observed that a decrease in reaction time to 30 min at 5 bar H2 pressure and 50 °C resulted in only a slight loss of activity showing 85% conversion compared to 100% after 1 h (Table 1, entries 11 and 10) and it was improved to 100% by increasing H2 pressure to 10 bar (Table 1, entry 12). This is one of the mildest reaction conditions for the complete and selective conversion of LA to γ-VL in shortest time reported so far (Table S1 in the ESI). The HRO material amount used for the reaction is 3.5 mg for the hydrogenation of 1 g LA, and the inconvenience in using such a small quantity of the catalyst precursor may pose difficulty in recovering the entire catalyst from the reaction mixture. To circumvent this problem, we tried to impregnate the HRO material on assorted supports like carbon, TiO2, MgAl-LDH, H-β and cellulose with theoretical Ru content of 4 wt%. Among them, H-β zeolite showed a high degree of dispersion of HRO with higher Ru loading of 3.2 wt% as inferred from ICP-OES measurements. An initial reaction using 100 mg of HRO/H-β showed quantitative conversion of LA to γ-VL under the previously optimized reaction conditions of 10 bar H2 at 50 °C for 30 min (Table 1, entry 13). When weight of the catalyst was further decreased, a similar result (100% yield of γ-VL) was observed when the amount of HRO/H-β was 50 mg, and while in the case of 35 mg, though the selectivity of γ-VL was maintained, the conversion of LA decreased to 94% (Table 1, entry 14 and 15). Thus, further reactions were performed using 50 mg of HRO/H-β catalyst precursor (equivalent to 0.16 wt% of Ru w.r.t LA). The use of H-β zeolite support played a positive role by further decreasing the required Ru loading (compared to as such HRO), presumably due to the better dispersion of Ru centres on its surface thereby making the active sites available to react with LA. The recovery of supported catalyst (Ru-HRO@H-β) after the reaction by filtration is easier compared to simple Ru-HRO catalyst. Another aim of this study was to accomplish the production of γ-VL in very short time. To this effect, we increased the temperature progressively from 50 °C to 200 °C and the reaction time was reduced from 30 min to about 1.5 min under mentioned H2 pressure. Quantitative yields of γ-VL were obtained at 100 °C, 150 °C and 200 °C in 7 min, 3.5 min and 1.5 min respectively (Table 1, entries 14 and 16–19), rendering them amongst most accelerated conversions of LA to γ-VL. The catalytic activity of HRO catalyst precursor was compared with that of HRO-N synthesized with NaOH as the precipitating agent and also with commercial HRO procured from Sigma Aldrich (HRO-S). It was observed that HRO from all sources showed similar catalytic activity (Table 1, entries 20–22). Many Ruthenium-based catalysts were reported for LA to γ-VL conversion in which some of the catalysts showed excellent yield of γ-VL even at room temperature. For example, Y. Zhu et al. reported excellent catalytic activity for Ru/reduced graphene oxide (RGO), reduced at 150 °C, 40 bar H2, 2 h, for this reaction with 100% conversion of LA and 99.9% selectivity of γ-VL at room temperature in aqueous medium (Table 2 , entry 1). While on the contrary, under similar reaction conditions, the non-reduced catalyst (Ru/GO) was completely inactive suggests the absence of the active Ru(0) species under the conditions studied (Table 2, entry 2) [61]. W. Huang et al. disclosed few-layer graphene (FLG) supported reduced ruthenium catalyst (externally reduced via chemical reduction using polyol) which showed 98% yield of γ-VL at 20 °C at 40 bar H2 in 8 h (Table 2, entry 3) [62]. Furthermore, R. Palkovits’ research group have also demonstrated room temperature synthesis of γ-VL from neat LA using Ru/C with 97.5% yield in 50 h, and observed a decrease in the catalytic activity upon reuse (Table 2, entry 4) [37]. We explored the catalytic activity of in situ catalytic system, Ru-HRO@H-β, at room temperature with an endeavour to compare the activity with such externally reduced catalysts with maintaining similar Ru content and reaction conditions. The experiments were conducted with aqueous LA as etching of the reactor walls observed when concentrated LA solutions (>25 wt%) or neat LA was used. The present in situ catalytic system generated at ambient temperature (Ru-HRO@H-β) from HRO/H-β showed good activity compared to externally reduced catalysts. Under similar conditions, conventional ex situ reduced catalysts such as Ru/H-β, Ru/C, and Ru/Al2O3 showed moderate conversion of LA (24–33%) while Ru-HRO@H-β catalyst showed 70% (Table 2, entry 5–8). 3.3 Mechanistic studies Michael et al. reported that the catalytic activity of Ru increases in aqueous medium than while using in organic solvents, and attributed to the hydrogen bonding interaction of co-adsorbed water molecules with reactants on the catalyst surface, in other words facilitates easy access of reactants with the active sites of the catalyst [53]. Based on which, we conceived an idea that HRO based materials which are acidic and has strongly bonded water molecules to RuOx could serve as an efficient catalytic system for the conversion of LA to γ-VL. This material was previously reported to be effective for the conversion of cellulose to glucose [54]. Our idea was validated as Ru-HRO (derived from HRO) was found to be an exceptional catalyst for the selective conversion of LA to γ-VL under mild reaction conditions. Galletti et al. proposed two mechanistic pathways for the synthesis of γ-VL from LA. Path a involves the hydrogenation of LA to γ-hydroxypentanoic acid (γ-HP) followed by intramolecular esterification to obtain γ-VL, and path b in which the enol form of LA is esterified to α-angelica lactone (α-AL) followed by hydrogenation to γ-VL (Fig. S6 in the ESI) [36]. Using HRO material, the conversion of LA to γ-VL was too fast to observe either of the two reported intermediates, thus precluding the identification of the mechanistic pathway (Table 3 , entry 2). To pinpoint a mechanistic pathway, we employed methyl levulinate (ML) as the substrate instead of LA under our reaction conditions. If the reaction followed path a, the conversion of ML to γ-VL would involve transformation of ML to methyl γ-hydroxypentanoate which would then convert to γ-VL by intramolecular trans-esterification. The ML reaction product mixture contained 48% selectivity (32% yield) of un-cyclised methyl γ-hydroxypentanoate (M γ-HP) as observed by GC–MS (Table 3, entry 5). This observation supported that path a mechanism (hydrogenation followed by intramolecular esterification) is operating in LA to γ-VL conversion over this catalyst. Further, the LA in presence of HRO material and in the absence of H2 did not show the formation of α-angelica lactone (LA remained unconverted), which would be an expected intermediate if the reaction followed path b (Table 3, entry 6). Thus from above experiments, it can be concluded that the reaction undergoes through path a mechanism. The reaction conducted with simple RuO2 interestingly showed no activity for the reaction (Table 3, entry 1), indicating a clear evidence for the necessity of adsorbed water molecules on HRO for the conversion of LA to γ-VL. The bonded H2O molecules of HRO easily adsorb LA molecules on its surface through hydrogen bonding, and for this reason the HRO catalyst shows superior activity compared to other conventionally used Ru-based catalysts. In addition, TPR studies corroborated a lesser reduction temperature for HRO catalyst compared to RuO2. The reactivity of HRO material was assessed in other solvents besides in aqueous medium such as THF and methanol (Table 3, entries 3–4). Negligible activity was observed in them. This suggests the necessity of water molecules in the reaction and/or optimal concentration and particle size of Ru(0) formed in situ upon reduction of HRO, as corroborated from the PXRD measurements of the used catalyst which showed less intense reflection for Ru(0) in these solvents compared to while conducting the reaction in H2O (Fig. 3C). In other words, aqueous medium is only favourable for facile reduction of HRO. Initially, the Run+ of HRO undergoes reduction to Ru(0) which is the active species for hydrogenation. In presence of this in situ formed Ru(0), the hydrogen molecules get absorbed on the metal surface and form metal-hydrogen bond. Theoretical calculations reported show that even a single chemisorbed water molecule on Ru catalyst is enough for enhancing the catalytic hydrogenation activity of ketones [53,55]. The adjacent of Ru-H might have H2O molecules adsorbed on unreduced HRO that interact with LA through hydrogen bonding, and would undergo hydrogenation to γ-HP by attacking of H of Ru. The formed γ-HP, being unstable, undergo immediately intramolecular esterification and forms the γ-VL. Based on the above discussions, a proposed reaction mechanistic pathway is given in Fig. 1 . 3.4 In situ formation of Ru(0) from HRO during the reaction: characterization study The nature of HRO material and Ru metal formed under the reaction conditions were monitored by various analytical techniques like PXRD, XPS, SEM, TEM, TPR, TGA and FT-IR. The fresh HRO material was amorphous in nature as confirmed by lack of any diffraction peaks in PXRD. However, after the reaction, the obtained material showed a peak at 2θ = 43° (101 plane) that could be ascribed to hexagonal closed-packed (hcp) structure of Ru (Fig. 3A), confirming the occurrence of reduction of HRO to Ru(0) under the reaction conditions. The FT-IR spectrum of HRO showed an intense band at ∼3440 cm−1 that corresponds to O-H stretching vibration of adsorbed hydrogen-bonded H2O molecules. This band was also observed for the used catalyst after the reaction (Ru-HRO-2, 2 stand after 2nd cycle), however, with reduced intensity. This suggests that the HRO material is not fully reduced to Ru(0) in one cycle, and the reduction of HRO gradually occurs and increases with the reaction cycles. RuO2 which is inactive for the reaction showed a very weak band in the above range probably due to the presence of physisorbed or weakly-held H2O molecules (Fig. 4). To know the reduction property increment of HRO (unsupported) while increasing the reaction cycles were confirmed by PXRD. Recovered the material from 1st (Ru-HRO), 3rd (Ru-HRO-3), and 5th (Ru-HRO-5) cycles dried and used for analysis. The reaction conditions and PXRD profile of above mentioned cycles were mentioned in Fig. 3B. Increasing the intensity of Ru(0) peak (2θ = 43°; 101 plane) with increasing the reaction cycles recovered material was observed. Similar observation was noted for the H-β supported catalyst as well wherein for the first cycle obtained material (Ru-HRO@H-β), Ru(0) peak is not intense while after the 5th cycle, the obtained material (Ru-HRO@H-β-5) showed good intense peak of Ru(0). Further, the decrease in concentration of H2O molecules upon reaction cycles was also confirmed by TGA analysis, wherein fresh HRO showed a weight loss of up to 24% in the temperature range 150–350 °C due to the removal of strongly bound H2O molecules, while the weight loss in the similar range was 6% for Ru-HRO-2. This attests to the fact that even after the reduction, some of the water molecules are still adsorbed and available (Fig. 5). The reduction behaviour of HRO catalyst precursor to Ru(0) metal under the reaction conditions was further supported by TPR analysis (Fig. 6). The TPR of both fresh HRO and Ru-HRO-2 showed a reduction peak around 200–600 °C, however, with a reduced intensity for latter which confirms that the catalyst was not reduced in one reaction cycle. The SEM and TEM images of HRO material showed highly agglomerated particles expected due to the Ru-O-Ru linkage in the fresh catalyst precursor. After the reaction, the used catalyst (Ru-HRO-2) showed a decrease in agglomeration suggesting the breakage of Ru-O-Ru linkages while forming Ru metal (Figs. 7A–B and S5A–B). In situ Ru(0) formation under reaction conditions was also supported by electron binding energies (eV) using XPS measurements (Fig. 8 A). XPS of HRO material exhibited peak at 282.7 eV, arising from the 3d5/2 electron and assigned to Ru(+6) of RuO3. Another peak of HRO at 281.3 eV corresponds to 3d5/2 of RuO2(+4) [56–60]. The HRO material under reaction conditions in presence of H2 is reduced from Ru(+4) to Ru(0) and Ru(+6) to Ru(+4) as confirmed by the shift in the peak positions from Ru (+6) of HRO 282.7 (3d5/2) eV to Ru(+4) at 281.3 (3d5/2), the Ru(+4) of HRO 281.3 (3d5/2) to Ru(0) with peak positions at 280.1 (3d5/2) (Fig. 8B). In addition, the BET surface area of HRO decreased after the reaction (Ru-HRO) to 59 m2/g and similar observation was noted even for supported material (397 m2/g for HRO/H-β to 361 m2/g for Ru-HRO@H-β). The decrease in the surface area could possibly be due to change in the nature of ruthenium owing to the ‘in situ’ reduction (Table 4). 3.5 Recyclability of catalyst Assessment of recyclability of catalyst is necessary when using precious metal catalysts for industrial applications. After each cycle, the Ru-HRO@H-β catalyst was separated by simple centrifugation and was used as such for the next cycle without any pre-treatment. This procedure was followed for five consecutive cycles and no loss in the catalytic activity was observed at 100 °C, 10 bar H2 for 10 min (Fig. S7A in the ESI). To know the actual stability/activity of catalyst, we monitored the reusability while simultaneously evaluating the kinetics at a lower temperature (60 °C), 10 bar H2, and at different time intervals (20, 40, and 60 min) showed in Fig. S7B in the ESI. We observed upon reuse a slight decrease in the catalytic activity of Ru-HRO@H-β (in the initial 20 min. of the reaction). This could possibly due to hindered diffusion and binding of LA molecules on the surface of the catalyst (and in turn on the approach towards the active site Ru(0)) due to continued removal of water molecules upon reuse (Figs. 4 and 5). It is worth mentioning here that in all reuse studies, 100% selectivity was observed for γ-VL. Furthermore, the ICP-OES data confirmed that the leaching of Ru was negligible even after the 5th catalytic cycle. 3.6 Scale-up study Scale-up studies were performed by progressively increasing the concentration of LA from 2.5 to 25 wt%. Negligible leaching of Ru was observed up to 12.5 wt% of LA; however, with a further increase to 25 wt% showed a considerable Ru leaching. The leaching studies at different concentration of LA are given in Table S2 in the ESI. A reaction with 12.5 wt% of LA at 20 g scale was conducted in aqueous medium using 1 g of HRO/H-β catalyst precursor at 50 bar H2, 150 °C for 30 min. Further, this reaction was conducted 9 times to confirm the reproducibility. All reactions showed 99–100% yield of γ-VL (Fig. S8 in the ESI). The aqueous product mixture was extracted with dichloromethane and evaporated using a rotary evaporator to obtain pure γ-VL. The collected DCM was reused for subsequent extractions. 3.7 Continuous production of γ-VL Continuous liquid phase hydrogenation of LA to γ-VL using HRO/H-β (3.2 wt% of Ru) catalyst precursor (dual bed 2 + 2 g) in aqueous medium using molecular H2 as hydrogen source was carried out. For this study, several parameters (60 h on catalytic bed) such as flow rate of aqueous LA (5 wt%) feed (2 to 1.5 ml), reaction temperature (225 to 75 °C), H2 pressure (20 to 5 bar), flow rate of H2 feed (50 to 2 ml/min) were varied. At optimised reaction conditions viz., 1.5 ml/min of aqueous LA feed flow, 100 °C, 10 bar H2 and 2 ml/min flow of H2, the catalyst showed complete conversion of LA with 99–100% yield of γ-VL for 40 h time-on-stream (60 to 100 h) (Fig. 9 ). Any deactivation and leaching of Ru was not observed during the continuous phase reaction; however, after 100 h, draining/oozing of catalytic bed from the reactor was observed as the reaction was performed in liquid flow. The flow force is effected on the removal of the catalytic bed. Reaction under continuous phase also followed similar mechanism viz., through the hydroxypentanoic intermediate pathway, confirmed by using ML as substrate. 4 Conclusions We have successfully demonstrated HRO as an efficient catalyst precursor for hydrogenation of LA to γ-VL in high yield (100%) under mild reaction conditions (example 50 °C, 10 bar H2 for 30 min) in aqueous medium. Mechanistic investigations studies through several analytical techniques such as PXRD, FT-IR, TGA, SEM, TPR, TEM and XPS unravelled that the ruthenium in HRO was reduced in situ to Ru(0), the active species for the reaction. Presence of bonded H2O molecules of HRO play a pivotal role in the facile production of γ-VL. The ease of reuse of HRO is demonstrated by supporting it on H-β catalyst and the supported catalyst is reusable up to five times without any loss in its activity. The catalyst also showed excellent activity and stability towards continuous liquid phase hydrogenation of LA to γ-VL with 99–100% yield under milder reaction conditions (100 °C) over 40 h time on stream. The present catalytic system has pronounced advantages including working under mild reaction conditions, using water as a solvent, facile and selective formation of γ-VL with avoiding the use of additives and/or co-catalysts that are commonly reported earlier in literature. Further, the endeavour of using in situ generated catalyst (Ru-HRO) to avoid conventionally deployed resource intensive external reduction for this reaction was also substantiated by its higher catalytic activity over the ‘ex situ’ generated catalyst. The report, thus establishes Ru-HRO as an eco-friendly new generation fast and selective hydrogenation catalyst, that works under mild reaction conditions. coredata.dc:description: A novel material, hydrous ruthenium oxide (HRO) as potential catalyst precursor, is reported for the selective hydrogenation of levulinic acid (LA) to γ-valerolactone (γ-VL) in high yields under the mildest conditions in an aqueous medium. Various characterization studies such as PXRD, FT-IR, TGA, SEM, TEM and XPS show that the active catalyst, referred here as Ru-HRO is generated in situ from HRO during the reaction. Such in situ generation of the active catalyst thus avoided prior reduction or pre-treatment which is often reported for Ru-based catalysts for this reaction. It is pertinent to mention that the activity of the in situ generated catalyst is higher than the ex situ reduced catalyst. The effect of H-β as support for HRO showed a pronounced influence on the active catalyst (Ru-HRO@H-β) by decreasing the Ru loading required (compared to ‘as such’ HRO) and rendered easier separation after the reaction. Interestingly, the HRO-derived catalyst works only under aqueous medium unlike in many organic solvents reported elsewhere. A reaction mechanism is proposed by using several controlled experiments which reveal hydrogenation of LA to γ-hydroxypentanoic acid (γ-HP) and followed by cyclisation (intramolecular esterification) to γ-VL with the removal of H2O. The catalyst showed similar activity upon recycling for up to five cycles and for the reaction scale (of LA) from 1 g to 200 g. Further, liquid phase continuous hydrogenation of LA to γ-VL is successfully demonstrated using in situ generated Ru-HRO@H-β (dual bed) in aqueous medium under optimized reaction condition (1.5 ml/min of aqueous LA feed flow (5 wt%), 100 °C, 10 bar H2 and 2 ml/min flow of H2 feed), that showed complete conversion of LA with 98–100% yield of γ-VL for 40 h time-on-stream. Simple preparation method, milder reaction conditions, high activity, recyclability, and ability to deploy under continuous conditions makes this catalytic process attractive for industrial production of γ-VL.
